newsitem.title: DENMARK: Denmark, Iceland to continue fish row talks soon.
newsitem.headline: Denmark, Iceland to continue fish row talks soon.

text.p: Denmark said on Friday it planned to hold more talks with Iceland soon in an attempt to resolve a North Atlantic fisheries row following two days of discussions between officials in the Danish capital.

"The talks were aimed at reaching both a permanent and an interim solution on fishing areas. The parties agreed to continue their consultations in Reykjavik in the near future," the Danish Foreign Ministry said in a statement
The dispute was sparked by recent Icelandic demands that Danish vessels cease fishing a 10,000 square km (4,000 sq mile) area in the Denmark Strait between east Greenland and Iceland.
Last month Danish and Icelandic ministerial delegations held a first round of unsuccessful negotiations on the issue in the Icelandic capital Reykjavik.
Also under discussion are fishing rights in the North Atlantic between the Faroe Islands and Iceland.
In an incident in July, an Icelandic fisheries inspection vessel forced three Danish trawlers to quit the fishing area off Greenland.

Denmark maintains the two countries agreed in talks in Reykjavik in 1988 that trawlers with licences from Greenland, Denmark and Iceland would be allowed to fish in the so-called grey zone, which is rich in capelin.
Copenhagen conducts foreign policy for Greenland and the Faroe Islands, which have home rule under the Danish crown.
Iceland fought and won a protracted cod war with Britain in the 1970s.
